ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 2-3 hours
great
Depending on the week (and which assignments were due) 2-10 hours
2 to 3
About 2 hours on average

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: It was overall a very interesting and informative course. I personally didn't enjoy the exclusive focus on research, and feel there should be more variety offered in a course that is a requirement of the Global Health Concentration. It definitely shouldn't be listed as a policy class any longer.

I wish they would honestly change the title. It is very misleading. I thought the class was going to focus on the leading issues facing global health today (ex. climate change, antibiotic resistance, obesity, nutrition, etc...) but instead it primarily focused on doing research in low to middle income countries.
great

Course was great! The weekly reading reflections helped me stay on top of the readings but didn't feel like a burden to do at all. Loved the set up of the course and how much class involvement was encouraged. Guest lectures and panels were super informative.
Good

I really enjoyed this course! It definitely deepened my interest in global health. The speakers were interesting, the paper was manageable (I liked that it was broken into sections due at different times), I liked that you could pick which weeks to do the reading summaries. I LOVED the poster session on the last day! That was a highlight of the semester for me. My only suggestions: Attendance should be mandatory and tracked. It was frustrating when we would have these incredible, high-profile speakers visit, and then only have a small number of students.

Strengths: faculty panels were excellent, I really enjoyed being able to hear from all those people who have had meaningful and impactful careers; course-long project was also really great, especially for us non-EMD people who aren't really given the opportunity to develop research proposals like that in our other courses. Improvements: changing the role of the student presenters- I think it was a better experience when they guided discussions instead of just presenting reading facts at the beginning of class (as we sometimes didn't have time to always discuss the questions the group posed)

Kaveh approaches global health topics with a perspective that I felt was very valuable for us to get as students early in our careers in global health. He helped us to think about ethical issues inherent in university research in low and middle income countries, and I feel like I am leaving the course with a greater depth of understanding of the complexity of work in global health.

This course is amazing, one of the best 3 courses I have taken at Yale School of Public Health. Readings for the course were excellent and reflected weekly themes which followed and contributed to the bigger theme of the course. The professor clearly put a lot of effort and thought into planning this course which is why it was a very effective discussion on multiple aspects of academic research in global health setting, its responsibilities, challenges and the way in which it can be used for furthering the global health field and health worldwide. Best run panels from any class. The capstone assignment for the course was a very useful exercise in ethical research project planning, and the poster session was a great way to understand and be exposed to other students' projects and areas of interest.
It was a good class exploring various topics in global health. Thoughtful discussions were held and you got out of it what you put into it.
great

Strengths: maintained common thread throughout a survey of material Weaknesses: felt like there was too much different material - led to a feeling of being spread too thin. Would have liked to have been able to focus more on one main area each week, especially for the faculty panel portions

I think this course was a great survey of different issues in global health as well as contemporary approaches for mitigating these issues. I really liked the course structure, which removed much of the pedagogy insofar that students presented every week and the class was truly run like a discussion instead of a lecture. The one weakness I see is that many student didn't show up on most days given that we were held to an honor code, I think this is not good for a classroom setting where we are all supposed to be learning from each other's experiences.
Strengths: Phenomenal Teaching Fellows
Very research-centered, so might not be great for students who are not interested in research. The speakers who came in were incredible
Very good- loved the range of topics that were covered and the meaningful discussions that took place.
i wish i came out of it with tangible skills in tackling global health issues. we mostly just had guest lecturers. i wanted to have actual lessons taught by kaveh.

Overall, the class was good for exposing us to a lot of different professionals in the global health field. I feel like I learned about things that I never did before. I also appreciated how the work on the research proposal was done incrementally. However, it would have been nice to go into deeper dives with some of these topics instead of just skimming the surface. Perhaps every week, a small cohort of students can sign up to get lunch with the main speaker(s) after class if it's a topic they are particularly interested kind of like the Healthcare Colloquium? Also, I don't think many students felt very incentivized to go to class every time/felt bad for not going. Also, it may be good to alter the class so that it is not solely research based because not all students who are interested in global health want to approach it from a research lens (some may want to be more policy based)
The course is not so practical but does help students to think about issues in global health. Very interesting guest speakers.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh was a very interesting professor, I feel there was a lot more we could have learned from him if he took a more active role in the course rather than having student presentations and guest speakers almost every course.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  He is fantastic!

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh has a tendency to want to talk over guest lecturers. If you invite them there please let them speak. If you want to talk about some subjects then stop having so many guest lectures. That was like 90% of the class.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  great
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh is a gem among YSPH professors. He is kind, helpful, and really cares about his students.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Excellent

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh was great! He is intelligent, kind, and well-connected in the global health world. It was interesting to learn about his projects over the years, and he was very open to student feedback.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Fantastic instructor- did a great job connecting students with resources and bringing in a diverse range of professionals to speak with us.

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh has so much amazing experience to share and genuinely cares about imparting his experiences and knowledge onto the next generation of public health professionals in terms of engaging in global health work with the most ethical perspective possible.

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  I have nothing but good words to say about the professor. Clearly extremely articulated presenter, put a lot of work and thought into building a strong course. He has an unparalleled skill for explaining concepts and leading productive discussions.

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  In a school full of uninspiring and disappointing professors, Kaveh was a breath of fresh air. Kaveh clearly cared about us as students and about our learning. I looked forward to his class every week which is not something I can say about literally any other class I took this semester. Kaveh was an exceptional professor.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  great
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Poses provocative questions, but can sometimes feel a little too rhetorical in teaching style
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Excellent, very thoughtful.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Approachable, knowledgeable
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh is a wonderful instructor and loves to hear the thoughts and opinions of his students which I really admire
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  It was very easy to see Kaveh's passion for Global Health. He was very approachable and conducted the class in a way that challenged and inspired students.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  very knowledgeable, great field experience. i wish he was a better instructor because his research and work are really inspiring, and we couldve learned a lot from him.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Instructor is great. You can tell he is very passionate about this work and he is very encouraging to his students.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Able to guide conversations and invite noteable speakers to class.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would say it's an excellent course for a student interested in global health research, and still interesting and informative for those just interested in global health.
It's a good course about global health research but not a good course about the current global health challenges.
great

Great course! Weekly topics are interesting and the readings are great. Readings were fairly easy to get done quickly. Research proposal was a fun assignment. I do think students would benefit if the course was in the fall and therefore they could pursue actually conducting the research the following summer.
Great
Take it! And show up to lectures, the guest speakers are worth it.

Great opportunity to engage in global health research and priority setting for students who do not have the opportunity to do this in their other courses. It is also a great way to learn and interact with global health professionals who work in areas around the world.
I highly recommend this course for anyone interested in working in global health or international development, either within or outside of academia.
Amazing introduction to aspects of research and topics of interest in global health, and a thoughtful conversation on ethical principles of global health.
This class was great. This class was the only class I looked forward to and the only class I was ever engaged in or learned anything in. You really get out of this class what you put into it.
A broad survey/overview of current global health problems and an evaluation of what global health actually is and means. Would recommend to someone planning to go abroad.
Absolutely recommend. It was really opening and shifted my world view.
If they were interested in global health research, then I would recommend it!
Definitely recommend, very interesting course!
I would definitely recommend this course to those interested in Global Health, specifically if you want to do research.

i would not recommend the class to another student because i felt like it was a waste of time. although we did get exposure to great lecturers, i wanted to come out with skills. we had to write our global health proposal with literally 0 instruction, and i struggled doing that on my own.

The course was okay--I feel like I learned a lot about global health but I think if there can be explicit opportunities for more networking with the faculty that come that would be great. You will be challenged to think about things in different ways and you will gain a lot of knowledge. However, sometimes it was easy for the class to be an afterthought. I would recommend it to a student if they want to learn broadly about global health topics generally, but not for deep dives.
If you would like to know the breadth of issues in global health then take this class. If you are looking for something more structured then I would not recommend it.
